title: How can gravity slow down time, if time isn’t something tangible you can touch? - Quora

response.answer_text: Brilliant question. The answer is actually very simple. Time, is something that things do. The word “time” is a term describing our motion through the temporal dimension. In simple terms, motion from one moment to the next. Gravity affects the rate at which things time. Time doesn't exist the way physical things exist. It exists the way “motion” exists. You can't touch motion, but you can measure how far things move. You can't touch time, but you can measure how far things time. Time is a verb. So, gravity affects the rate at which atomic, biological and mechanical processes occur. This includes our rate of perception. Now, subjectively, we perceive time passing as changes occurring around us and to us. We see things get older. So gravity not only affects the rate at which things “get older”, but also the rate at which we perceive things “getting older”. Gravity slows down the rate at which things time. NB, you won't find this explanation in any physics book. It's something I came up with after reviewing all the evidence. If you enjoyed this answer, click on the link. Philosophy of Relativity

Consider time as a dimension, just like spatial dimensions. You can move down a street at a speed in distance in length and in time. You cannot touch “distance” and yet we can travel at different lengths. Time is viewed as a dimension, according to the Theories of Relativity. Anyway, how indeed? I aimed to answer this somewhere else. Here is my answer. Hope it helps:  To understand this strange and counter-intuitive phenomenon, it helps to realize that constant acceleration is effectively the same as gravity (aka “the principle of equivalence”). Also why “Acceleration Time Dilation” and “Gravitational Time Dilation” are two labels for the same.   In the pictures above (from the brilliant movie; "2001: A Space Odyssey" (1968)), gravity is achieved by spinning, which scientifically equals a constant uniform acceleration. In science, constant acceleration and gravity are equivalent. It helps, when we need to understand how gravity may affect the flow of time. Imagine that you are standing inside an elevator in deep space, and it is being pulled at a fixed rate of increased acceleration. In this scenario, there would be no way for you to figure out if you were on a planet with gravity or if you were being pulled in space.  Now, Imagine a very long elevator in space.Imagine the elevator has someone standing on the floor, with a regular ticking watch. Let us call him Niels.Imagine someone about to pull the elevator (he is faraway outside, and pulling in the direction of the ceiling). Let us call him Albert.Imagine the elevator has a light-pulse-watch on the ceiling. It sends a light pulse every second - 60 a minute - straight down to Niels on the floor.Niels receives 60 light pulses every minute from this ceiling light-pulse-watch.Now, imagine Albert pulls the elevator, and thereby create acceleration in the direction of the ceiling (and so also gravitation inside the elevator - from the bottom up).Niels will experience an increase in gravity, because Niels is now being accelerated. Niels will also record more than 60 pulses a minute because he is being pulled in the direction of the pulses that are sent to him from the ceiling. You can say that he catches up to them (let us say he now receives 120 pulses in one of his minutes). However, the ceiling light-pulse-watch is still only sending 60 per minute. There can only be one of two explanations: 1: Either the speed of these light photons/pulses are variant, and changes as Niels is being pulled into them. From Niels’ perspective, the photons increase in speed. In other words; relative to Niels, the light-pulses become faster than light. 2: The time on the floor becomes slower than on the ceiling. Since the speed of light in a vacuum is the same for all observers, regardless of their motion relative to the source, it cannot be the first explanation. There is no way that light can increase its speed, even relative to Niels. The speed of light is always c, even when Niels is being pulled towards it. Ergo, it must be the second option: Time is now different. Niels must conclude that when just 60 seconds passed at the floor where he is, 120 seconds must have passed at the ceiling where this light-pulse-watch is. Niels’s clock ticks slower now on the elevator floor, when the acceleration (the gravity) increases. The stronger the gravity, the slower the time.    Attribution: I am often asked if Time Dilation has been confirmed? As expressed, in the article: yes it has, beyond any reasonable doubt. For reference, see, for example, these experiments: Pound–Rebka experiment (1959), Hafele–Keating experiment (1971), Gravity Probe A experiment (1976), Iijima et al. experiments (1975 - 1977), Chou et al. experiments (2010), Via our Particle Accelerators; fx (2014), van Baak et al. experiments (2005 - 2016) & Wayward Satellite Experiments (2019), etc. Photos via Google

Well Love is something intangible and abstract that tou Can not touch yet everyday people are convinced of the truth of it ? True? Gravity is a force created by the distortion and warp or the curvature of Spacetime ! Gravity seems to manipulate how time is perceived and moves this is true- Once we discovered the true relationship between Gravity And Spacetime and Electromagnetism we shall discover the Holy grail of Physics that Einstein was chasing all those years right up to the time of his death- Somtimes Called ……… EINSTEINS THEORY OF EVERYTHING……… or EINSTEINS UNIFIED FIELD THEORY ! A theory of everything (TOE or ToE), final theory, ultimate theory, or master theory is a hypothetical single, all-encompassing, coherent theoretical framework of physics that fully explains and links together all physical aspects of the universe. Finding a TOE is one of the major unsolved problems in physics. Over the past few centuries, two theoretical frameworks have been developed that, together, most closely resemble a TOE. These two theories upon which all modern physics rests are general relativity (GR) and quantum field theory (QFT). GR is a theoretical framework that only focuses on gravity for understanding the universe in regions of both large scale and high mass: stars, galaxies, clusters of galaxies, etc. On the other hand, QFT is a theoretical framework that only focuses on three non-gravitational forces for understanding the universe in regions of both small scale and low mass: sub-atomic particles, atoms, molecules, etc. QFT successfully implemented the Standard Model that describes the three non-gravitational forces: strong, weak, and electromagneticforce. Physicists have experimentally confirmed virtually every prediction made by these two theories when in their appropriate domains of applicability. In accordance with their findings, scientists also learned that GR and QFT, as they are currently formulated, are mutually incompatible – they cannot both be right. Since the usual domains of applicability of GR and QFT are so different, most situations require that only one of the two theories be used. As it turns out, this incompatibility between GR and QFT is only an issue in regions of extremely small scale - the Planck scale - , such as those that exist within a black hole or during the beginning stages of the universe (i.e., the moment immediately following the Big Bang). To resolve this incompatibility, a theoretical framework revealing a deeper underlying reality, unifying gravity with the other three interactions, must be discovered to harmoniously integrate the realms of GR and QFT into a seamless whole: the TOE is a single theory that, in principle, is capable of describing all phenomena in the universe. In pursuit of this goal, quantum gravity has become one area of active research. One example is string theory, which evolved into a candidate for the TOE, but not without drawbacks (most notably, its lack of currently testable predictions) and controversy. String theory posits that at the beginning of the universe (up to 10 seconds after the Big Bang), the four fundamental forces were once a single fundamental force. According to string theory, every particle in the universe, at its most microscopic level (Planck length), consists of varying combinations of vibrating strings (or strands) with preferred patterns of vibration. String theory further claims that it is through these specific oscillatory patterns of strings that a particle of unique mass and force charge is created (that is to say, the electron is a type of string that vibrates one way, while the up quarkis a type of string vibrating another way, and so forth). Gravity cannot slow down time, as there is no time to slow down. However, gravity can affect space and cause space to become denser or more rarefied. With less space to travel through, such as Mercury orbiting the Sun, Mercury can travel further than expected according to the calculations of Newton’s gravitational laws. The only real temporal dimension that the entire physical Universe experiences is the present. No physical matter has ever been measured at any other time interval into the past or future, which is just another way of saying there is no real past or real future as far as physics goes. What we experience in the present is frequency, which is the reciprocal of time. Frequency happens in the present moment. Velocity is equal to length times frequency. Even though scientists often prefer to speak about velocity as length per time (as though time was a real phenomenon), the physical world interpretation is actually length times frequency. The interpretation of Relativity theories, that time is sped up or slowed down, is poetic at best. Since there is no time, there is no time that can speed up or slow down. The concept of time travel, or even time dilation, is pure fantasy. The correct interpretation of a relativity theory is that space is distorted in some manner, which some people might interpret poetically as a time distortion.

Simple, practical answer. But you have to accept that gravity is the same as acceleration, so let’s show how acceleration ‘slows time down’. You are in a rocket and I am on earth. You start to accelerate away from me, flashing a light back to me once a minute. But as you start to go faster and faster, you get further and further away from me between flashes and they come back at the speed of light which is constant. So the gaps between your flashes get longer and longer and, if I am looking through your window, you will seem to me to be slowing down. So you are getting slower from where I am standing, so, relative to me your time is slowing down (yours isn’t, only relative to me). If I am outside a gravity ‘pool’ (or, more precisely, where it is much weaker) and you are inside it, you, your clock etc will also seem to be going slowly to me for the same reason. Not to you but to anyone outside the gravity pool. Gravity does not ‘slow time down’ but, relative to an observer ‘in less gravity’, your time will go slower. If you want to know why, when you come back in your rocket, you time does not speed up enough (and it does speed up) to match the time I think you slowed down on the way out, you need to ask that question. It has a simple but unexpected answer.

Why should the two be related? Being touchable is a rather special property of physical entities, which comes about, when there is a strong repulsive force between the entity and your hand, which drops off fast with the distance, so it appears there is an abrupt surface. So at a closer look, there is not really “stuff”, what appears tangible is just the action of a force as well. So if nothing is touchable, how can it have any effect? Well, the question is meaningless, because the assumption that forces are conveyed by “things” touching each other is wrong.

One of the most revelatory and insightful books I’ve ever read was lent to me decades ago by a friend, and I have since recommended it and gifted it to my fellow non-physicist friends. It’s out of print, but available in used condition on the web. One of the blurb-writers on the back cover even opines that the author may have understood Einstein’s theory better than Einstein himself. You’ll thank me later if you read this excellent book.  Relativity Visualized: The Gold Nugget of Relativity Books Perfect for those interested in physics but who are not physicists or mathematicians, this book makes relativity so simple that a child can understand it. By replacing equations with diagrams, the book allows non-specialist readers to fully understand the concepts in relativity without the slow, painful progress so often associated with a complicated scientific subject. It allows readers not only to know how relativity works, but also to intuitively understand it.

Time itself is not slowed down. Time passes more slowly as you descend into a gravitational field. What does that mean? Take two identical clocks. Put on on top of a mountain, and the other at sea level. Allow them to run for a while, and then bring them together and compare them. If the clocks are sufficiently accurate you will find that less time passed on the clock at lower altitude. That’s what that means. The why is that properties of space and time are affected by the presence of matter as given by the equations of General Relativity.

Time intervals can be measured by physical devices called "clocks", because clocks behave according to physical principles that include intangible time. Differences in speed between two identical clocks depend on differences in the gravitational potential at their locations. For example, when a clock on Earth is used to measure time, it will measure that an identical clock above it runs faster and one below it runs slower. That physical effect can be expressed (poorly, I think) by saying gravity changes the speed of time. To avoid worries about time being intangible, I recommend saying how clocks behave, rather than how time behaves.

I Think that time is just dependend upon light and its speed or in other words it motion. when the distance for light increases it slows down the time around it . for example imagine that light speed had decreased till 2m/s . so the time around us will just slow down . as the light would take much longer time to reach that object and again come back to your eyes . thus the time will slow down this is what Einstine called as time dilation . when an object moves at higher speed the time surrounding it decreases . because the light take more time to go near that observer eye and again come back to that object with that constant speed. so i think that time is non other than the speed of light and the motion and position of that object in the space. thank you

Time as we know and use it is something that ancients realized would be a most useful tool for creating their schedule for life. From the seconds up through the 365 day year, it is IMO, the greatest tool ever invented by a people with no outwardly known abilities other than the power of observing their surroundings. The Sun, Moon, weather to name a few became the inputs into creating how incriminates of time were developed. So if IMO, time doesn’t truly exist, then how could gravity have an affect?

It can’t. What it CAN do is slow down the oscillation rate of atomic particles. If some half evolved creatures want to make instruments from them and call them ‘clocks’ then it’s only their silly fault if they don’t understand things. Note that OTHER acceleration from the ‘state of origin’ of a particle does the same. The other related effect is changes to the propagation speed of EM SIGNALS after emission at regular intervals (including by anything we call a ‘clock’). That’s really just Doppler shift.

Gravity can slow down the speed of light, if you were near a black hole the light would be slowed down where you were but you wouldn’t notice, observers existing far enough from your location would see you slowing down though as they would not be affected. We can’t touch air yet we can bottle it, we can’t touch magnetism but we can use it to move objects that are affected by it. Gravity is not an idea, it is a force.

Time refers to the metric used in measuring the rate of actions, or changes. It is not a tangible material thing, it is a concept. Gravity slows down the rate of actions occurring in the field. How? This was not discussed in general relativity. GR only predicts the degree of curvature of the paths of mass and massless objects moving in the field, and other artifacts of time “dilation”.

Although exceedingly difficult to visualize and comprehend, it is understood today that time and space are intimately connected and are aspects of something deeper called space-time. Time as an aspect of space-time is much like length and breadth and height as aspects of space. And objects move through space-time at the invariant speed of light so that the faster an object moves through space the slower it must move through time.

Just to be clear, when we talk about time “slowing” in a grav field we mean that relative to someone in a weaker field. That is to say our time in the grav field isn’t slower to us. Observers in the lower grav field will look at us in a higher grav field and measure our time as ticking by more slowly than theirs. It’s not that gravity “affects” time. It affects how people in a different reference frame will measure that time relative to their own frame’s time. It’s a different metric.

It can’t. Gravity slows down clocks. Special relativity theory doesn’t recognize the difference, which is essential to the epistemology of time. So the error of reification of time is ubiquitous throughout relativity theory (including GR with its “flexible fabric of space-time” which also reifies space… emptiness.)

Time in the abstract is constant. The universe continues to exist constantly. However, gravity in certain places will effect how “objects in motion" move throughout the universe, some faster, some slower. If you're measuring those objects and their motion, you will start and stop at a given time. If you measure twice, you might get a different reading from the first due to the fluctuations in motion but not because of time itself.

Time is a measurement of motion. When things move in higher gravity it takes a longer interval of time to make that complete motion. I believe the reason for gravity is that space is more compressed the closer you get to the center of a mass. The more compressed space requires a longer interval of time to complete a motion because atoms and photons have to take a greater number of steps to complete the motion.
